Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: PYROLYSIS ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A Unique observation numberfor the pyrolysis analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: CALCULATED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that the value given wascalculated, rather than measured. If the REPORTED_IND is also set to Y, thecalculated value was provided by the source (usually the lab) and not calculatedlater. For more details about how the value was calculated, refer to theCALCULATE_METHOD_ID column and foreign key.
Column Comment.5: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifer for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.7: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.8: MAXIMUM TEMPERATURE: Often called Tmax in reports, this is the temperature ofthe maximum S2 peak. Temperature corresponding to the maximum rate ofhydrocarbons generated from the cracking of kerogen (S2). Depressed valuesindicate migrated hydrocarbons. For multiple peaks in S2, the one with the highestsignal will be assigned Tmax. Anomalously low and high Tmax values can result forthese mixed sources or drilling additives, while high Tmax (>500oC) can also resultfrom mineral decomposition.
Column Comment.9: MAXIMUM TEMPERATURE OUOM: Maximum temperature original unit of measure.
Column Comment.11: PEAK TEMPERATURE: Called Tpeak in reports. True temperature corresponding tothe maximum rate of hydrocarbons generated from the cracking of kerogen.Temperature measured inside of the oven. Tpeak is approximately 30oC greater thanTmax
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not pyrolysis analysis ispreferred.
Column Comment.16: PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is a problem withthe step. If a yes flag is indicated, additional information regarding the problemshould be noted in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.17: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.18: REPORTED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value is provided as reportedby the source, usually a laboratory. This indicates that the value was not created ormodified upon load into PPDM, even though the value may not be correct. Ifproblems are suspected, set PROBLEM_IND to Y, and for more details about whatproblems may exist, refer to the ANL_PROBLEM table.
Column Comment.19: REPORTED BITUMEN INDEX: Amount of free hydrocarbons (S1) normalized toTOC.BI = 100 * S1 / TOC. Usually reported with no decimal places, and in units ofmg/gTOC (milligrams per gram of Total Organic Carbon). This is a calculated valuethat should only be stored when capturing results as provided by a lab.
Column Comment.20: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.21: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.22: REPORTED OXYGEN INDEX: Amount of hydrocarbons released on pyrolysis (S2)normalized to TOC.HI = 100 * S2 / TOC. Usually reported with no decimal places,and in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams per gram of Total Organic Carbon). This is acalculatedvalue that should only be stored when capturing results as provided by alab. HI > 300 indicates oil-proneness. A theoretically maximum HI of 1206 is obtainedfor 100% conversion of the organic matter to hydrocarbons assuming the proportionof C in the organic matter is 0.83. For rocks with TOC < 3% the HI can besuppressed by up to 100%, resulting in the true hydrocarbon potential being severelyunderestimated. It is recommended that HI determined on isolated kerogen be usedfor organic-lean rocks.
Column Comment.23: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.24: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.25: REPORTED OXYGEN INDEX: Amount of carbon dioxide released on pyrolysisnormalized to TOC.OI = 100 * S3 / TOC. Usually reported with no decimal places,and in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams per gram of Total Organic Carbon). This is acalculated value that should only be stored when capturing results as provided by alab. Not reliable in carbonates and organically lean sediments. High values indicatelow hydrocarbon yields. Higher OIs occur in terrestrial organic matter wrt marineorganic matter.
Column Comment.26: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.27: REPORTED INDEX UOM: Usually reported in units of mg/gTOC (milligrams pergram of Total Organic Carbon)
Column Comment.28: REPORTED PRODUCTION INDEX: This value is unitless, usually reported to 2decimal places. Extent to which kerogen has been transformed into oil and gas. Thisis calculated as S1/S1+S2. Anomalous values may correspond to accumulation ordrainage of hydrocarbons or contamination
Column Comment.29: REPORTED PYROLYSABLE CARBON: The amount of TOC represented by S1 andS2.; PC = 0.83* (S1+S2). Oxidation of organic matter lowers these values.
Column Comment.32: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.33: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample.
Column Comment.34: S 0 VALUE: S0 - Volatilized gas fraction
Column Comment.36: S 1 VALUE: S1 - Volatilized free oil fraction, Measure of the amount of freehydrocarbons present in the rock. The free hydrocarbons are those thermallydesorbed at 300oC for 3 minutes. Can be severely affected (high values) byoil-based drilling fluid (see Traps and Tips)
Column Comment.38: S 2 VALUE: S2 - Hydrocarbons from pyrolysed kerogen fraction. Measure ofhydrocarbons formed by cracking of kerogen, resins and asphaltenes. The pyrolysateis measured from 300oC to 650oC at 25oC/min. High values may be obtained if oil orbitumen is present (Clementz, 1980) and mineral decomposition. Drilling additivesalso cause problems. Lower values can arise from adsorption on the mineral matrix(Espitalie et al., 1980; Orr, 1983). The later suppression can be eliminated usingisolated kerogen.
Column Comment.40: S 3 VALUE: S3 - Carbon dioxide from pyrolysed kerogen fraction. Measure of CO2generated from oxygenated functional groups in kerogen. The CO2 is collected from300oC to 390oC at 25oC/min. Subject to interference by CO2 from decomposition ofcarbonate minerals (Horsfield and Douglas, 1980; Horsfield, 1984).
Column Comment.42: S 4 VALUE: S4 - Carbon dioxide from oxidized residual carbon fraction
Column Comment.44: S5: The S5 value is the carbon dioxide from a mineral source.
Column Comment.46: TOTAL ORGANIC CARBON: Measure of the organic richness of the rock. Errors ofup to 10% can occur between LECO and Rock-Eval methods (coals are the mostdifficult to measure accurate values using the Rock-Eval method).
Column Comment.49: VALID ANALYSIS INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not the pyrolysisanalysis was valid according to the technician.
Column Comment.50: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.51: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.52: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.53: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.54: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.55: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.56: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
